thread.title: Everything you need to know about the refugee crisis

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Everything you need to know about the refugee crisis
text:
� Laszlo Balogh / Reuters/REUTERS Millions of people desperately seeking sanctuary are being met with hostility in places such as Hungary, who have sealed off their border with barbed-wire The worldwide refugee crisis has displaced a record 60 million people from their homes — the most since the end of World War II — pushing asylum systems to their limits.
People desperately fleeing death, destruction and abysmal living conditions in countries like Syria and Iraq to places in Central America and Africa have sparked a global panic.
And the commotion has left many world leaders struggling to find a way to remedy the problem.
Refugees, those fleeing due to fear of persecution or war, may apply for asylum outside their home country, and are eligible for certain legal protections, according to the U.N. Refugee Agency.
But compounding the problem for many countries who are offering asylum to refugees is the alarming number of migrants seeking better economic opportunities.
In the last year, civil war has forced 15 million people to flee Syria and Iraq; 1.1 million people have been displaced in Yemen; more than 500,000 have fled South Sudan; 190,000 in Burundi; and 300,000 in Libya, according to U.N. Refugee Chief Antonio Guterres.
Meanwhile, thousands are trying to escape gang violence in Central America, political unrest in Ukraine, and little to no progress has been made with regards to war-torn regions in the Central African Republic, Nigeria, and Congo.
Here is a short guide to where each country stands:
Syria © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS An estimated 7.6 million Syrians have been internally displaced due to violent conflicts in the country and a further 4 million have sought refuge abroad © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS Many Syrian refugees have made the dangerous journey across the Mediterranean to Greek islands © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS The conflict has put 2 million Syrian children out of school © Alexandros Avramidis / Reuter/REUTERS Many migrants and refugees have been received with hostility © Bernadett Szabo / Reuters/REUTERS Almost 12.8 million Syrians are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance © Alkis Konstantinidis / Reuter/REUTERS Around 220,000 Syrians have been killed in the conflict © Kai Pfaffenbach / Reuters/REUTERS More than half the Syrian population is currently displaced Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps Syria The conflict in Syria has displaced a record number of citizens over the past year.
An estimated 7.6 million civilians have been reportedly displaced within the country and another 4 million have sought refuge abroad, according to a report published by the European Commission in September .
The civil war began in 2011, after the country’s notorious leader, Bashar Al-Assad, started a violent campaign to combat a series of uprisings — known as the Arab Spring.
Chaos further escalated when jihadist Islamic State Militants — commonly referred to as ISIS — took advantage of the unstable nation and entered the country in a bid to create a totalitarian state under an Islamic Caliphate.
The militants have vowed to “(take) over the entire world and (behead) every last person that rebels against Allah," according to a document released by the terrorist group in July of this year.
Four years later, the situation inside Syria’s borders is dire.
A quarter of the nation’s schools have been destroyed — the conflict has put 2 million Syrian children out of school, according to UNICEF , some for more than four years — and more than half the nation’s hospitals have been destroyed, according to U.N. figures.
The Kurds NILUFER DEMIR/AFP/Getty Images The image of Alan Kurdi, the 3-year-old Kurdish boy who was found face down on a Turkish beach, caused international concern The image of Alan Kurdi, a 3-year-old Kurdish boy who washed up on a Turkish beach, opened the world’s eyes to the refugee crisis in September.
A large percentage of the Iraqi and Syrian refugees fleeing the raging conflicts are Kurds.
The Kurds — the fourth largest ethnic group in the Middle East — have never belonged to a permanent nation, and have faced brutal repression during most of their history.
Nearly 35 million Kurds reside in a mountainous region between Syria, Iraq, Iran, Armenia and Turkey. Kurds do not identify as Arabic, and most of them are Sunni Muslims, according to the BBC.
Peshmerga, the well-trained Kurdish security forces, have been fighting ISIS in Syria and Northern Iraq and the ongoing violence has resulted in millions fleeing the conflict.
Iraq © Philippe Wojazer / Reuters/REUTERS Since June 2015, 4 million Iraqis have been internally displaced © Pascal Rossignol / Reuters/REUTERS An aerial view of a field with tents and makeshift shelters, where migrants and asylum seekers are staying in Calais, France © Philippe Wojazer / Reuters/REUTERS Humanitarian aid to certain regions in the country has been restricted due to violent conflict © Philippe Wojazer / Reuters/REUTERS One out of five of the 3.2 million displaced Iraqis are living in critical shelter arrangements Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps Iraq Since ISIS took over the region of Mosul in 2014 — sparking widespread violence throughout the country — a staggering 4 million civilians have been internally displaced, according to the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre.
Humanitarian aid to certain regions in the country — particularly central Iraq — has been restricted due to the conflict. And the number of Iraqi civilians seeking refuge in other countries is rising considerably, according UNHCR figures .
“Massive displacement due to continued conflict persists across Iraq, and displaced Iraqis are in increasingly desperate situations,” said International Organization for Migration’s Iraq Chief of Mission Thomas Lothar Weiss.
“Of the nearly 3.2 million displaced, one out of five are living in critical shelter arrangements, including unfinished buildings and informal settlements,” he said.
Yemen Mosa'ab Elshamy/AP Ashwaq, 12, stands outside her family's tent, at the Markaze refugee camp in Obock, northern Djibouti. Mosa'ab Elshamy/AP In this Wednesday, May 20, 2015 photo, a Yemeni refugee walks at the yard of an orphanage that has been turned into a center for Yemeni refugees, in Obock, northern Djibouti. Mosa'ab Elshamy/AP In this Tuesday, May 19, 2015 photo, Abo Bakr Mohammed, 12, who suffers from epilepsy, covers himself with a mosquito net in his family's room, at an orphanage that has been turned into a center for Yemeni refugees. Mosa'ab Elshamy/AP Yemeni refugees play football outside the Markaze refugee camp where Yemeni refugees are stationed, in Obock, northern Djibouti. Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps Yemen This year, more than 1,500 civilians have been killed in the conflict in Yemen, and more than 3,600 injured.
At present, there are 1.1 million Yemenis fleeing the ongoing conflict, according to U.N. refugee chief, Antonio Guterres.
The conflict has been dubbed as a proxy war between Shiite powerhouse Iran, backing Houthi rebels, and Sunni-dominated Saudi Arabia — which borders with Yemen, according to The Associated Press .
Shiite Iran has accused the Saudis of supporting Sunni militants — including ISIS militants in Syria and Iraq.
Since the conflict peaked earlier this year, land, air and maritime restrictions have significantly reduced imports like food and other basic essentials. Humanitarian access has been significantly restricted, too, due to the ongoing violence, according to the U.N.
Afghanistan © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS Afghan refugees arrive on the Greek island of Lesbos after crossing a part of the Aegean sea from Turkey © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS A dinghy overcrowded with Afghan refugees arrives on the Greek island of Lesbos © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS The ongoing conflict in Afghanistan has resulted in the longest displacement situation in recorded history © Yannis Behrakis / Reuters/REUTERS Over 2.6 million Afghan refugees are displaced around the world © Alkis Konstantinidis / Reuter/REUTERS A migrant boy from Afghanistan sits on the staircase of a deserted hotel on the Greek island of Kos © Alkis Konstantinidis / Reuter/REUTERS Mattresses used by migrants are seen at the lobby of a deserted hotel on the Greek island of Kos © Alkis Konstantinidis / Reuter/REUTERS Over 1,500 Afghan civilians have been killed in the conflict this year and over 3,000 have been injured Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps Afghanistan The ongoing conflict in Afghanistan has resulted in the longest displacement situation in recorded history, according to the U.N. Refugee Agency.
Over 2.6 million Afghan refugees are displaced around the world — the majority of whom have fled to nearby countries like Iran and Pakistan.
The UNHCR estimates that 14% of refugees who arrived to Europe by boat are Afghan refugees fleeing the intensifying conflict within Afghanistan’s borders.
In the first half of this year, over 1,500 civilians have been killed in the conflict in Afghanistan, and over 3,000 have been injured, according to The U.N. Assistance Mission in Afghanistan and the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights.
“The rise in the numbers of women and children killed and maimed from conflict-related violence is particularly disturbing,” said Danielle Bell, the Director of Human Rights at UNAMA .
President Obama announced last week that the U.S. will keep 5,000 troops in Iraq until 2017, as Afghan security forces are not yet prepared to hold off the Taliban alone.
South Sudan � Juan Medina / Reuters/REUTERS The South Sudanese conflict began in December 2013 � Darrin Zammit Lupi / Reuters/REUTERS Almost 1,000 people have been killed in the conflict this year � Eric Gaillard / Reuters/REUTERS A migrant sleeps covered by an Union-Jack flag � Juan Medina / Reuters/REUTERS Due to displacement and the dry climate, millions of people cannot grow or harvest crops � Juan Medina / Reuters/REUTERS Many Sudanese migrants have fled to Calais, France, and are staying at "The New Jungle" camp � Juan Medina / Reuters/REUTERS Coexistence between refugees and settled communities has been an issue in some regions � Juan Medina / Reuters/REUTERS Sudanese migrants construct a makeshift shelter at "The New Jungle" camp in Calais, France Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps South Sudan The South Sudanese conflict began in December 2013, and the civilian population of the world’s youngest country are still enduring the consequences of it — with more than 1.5 million people displaced as of this month.
Almost 1,000 people have been killed in the conflict this year, and over 10,000 last year, according to UNHCR .
The brutal conflict pits President Salva Kiir's army against those loyal to rebel leader Riek Machar, a former deputy president, who President Kiir says planned a coup to overthrow the government — Machar says the president of South Sudan was trying to quash political opposition.
Due to displacement and the dry climate millions cannot grow or harvest crops — making the prospect of famine a real possibility in the country.
Coexistence between refugees and settled communities has been an issue in some regions due to scarce resources in communities already suffering from malnutrition — possibly precipitating a famine, according to UNHCR.
Burundi Jerome Delay/AP Unprecedented numbers fleeing the conflict in Burundi have had devastating consequences Jerome Delay/AP Burundi riot police firing tear gas chase demonstrators during clashes in Bujumbura, Burundi Gildas Ngingo/AP Burundian President of the Independent National Electoral Commission, Pierre Clave Ndayicariye Gildas Ngingo/AP Over 190,000 refugees have fled Burundi since the beginning of April this year Gildas Ngingo/AP Burudians march in Bujumbura Musaga Neighborhood Gildas Ngingo/AP Mourners march and sings songs against President Nkurunziza for running for a third term Jerome Delay/AP Refugees who fled Burundi's violence and political tension reach a ship freighted by the UN, at Kagunga on Lake Tanganyika, Tanzania Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps Burundi Over 190,000 refugees have fled Burundi since the beginning of April, when President Nkurunziza announced he would stand for a third term, according to the UNHCR .
The unprecedented numbers fleeing the violent political unrest has had disastrous results — including an outbreak of cholera.
President Nkurunziza was sworn in for a third term in August, and called on refugees to return to the country to help rebuild the nation.
Libya � Darrin Zammit Lupi / Reuters/REUTERS This year a ship carrying more than 1,000 Libyan migrants sank and killed over 800 people � Darrin Zammit Lupi / Reuters/REUTERS Many displaced people arriving to Italy by sea are coming from Libya Previous Next Enlarge Google Maps Libya In June, reports showed that the figures of Libyans fleeing conflict had doubled to more than 434,000 compared to September 2014. These numbers are not confirmed, however, due to limited access to dangerous regions, according to UNHCR.
Many displaced people arriving to Italy by sea are coming from Libya facilitated by human traffickers, who exploit migrants and refugees by charging them thousands of dollars for their help and subject them to violence and abuse.
This year a ship carrying more than 1,000 Libyan migrants sank and killed over 800 people , making it the deadliest incident in the Mediterranean Sea in recorded history, according to the United Nations.
Eritrea © Pascal Rossignol / Reuters/REUTERS The number of Eritreans seeking refuge in Europe due to atrocious human rights violations is currently estimated at 5,000 people a month Google Maps Eritrea 2015 Eritreans are the second largest nationality after Syrians to cross the Mediterranean Sea to Europe, according to Mike Smith , Chairperson of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in Eritrea.
The numbers seeking refuge in Europe due to atrocious human rights violations taking place in the country is currently estimated at 5,000 people a month.
Figures of those fleeing the country have nearly doubled over the past six years, according to the U.N. refugee agency.
“Since independence, ultimate power in Eritrea has remained largely in the hands of one man and one party. Those in control often rule arbitrarily and act with impunity...The Eritrean people have no say in governance and little control over many aspects of their own lives,” said Smith.
Germany has invested billions of euros in the refugee crisis and is expecting to receive up to 800,000 applications for asylum this year — the largest in Europe, according to Amnesty International.
The country’s vice-chancellor, Sigmar Gabriel, announced in September that they would take 500,000 asylum seekers a year for the next several years.
Speaking to reporters at an EU summit in Brussels last week, German Chancellor Angela Merkel called on other EU countries to fulfill their financial obligations in the midst of the crisis.
“Only a small number of countries have a great number of refugees and if they provide all of the personnel at the outer border,” Merkel said.
“Then that’s not what we understand as a fair distribution.”
In the last four years, Germany and Sweden combined have received 47% of the Syrian asylum applications in the EU.
The other 26 EU countries have pledged a meager 8,700 resettlement places for refugees, according to Amnesty International.
Arab countries Jordan, Turkey, Lebanon, Egypt and Iraq have taken in the majority of the Syrian refugees — with the five countries combined sheltering 4 million displaced people.
Wealthy gulf Arab states, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Qatar have not taken any refugees, according to Amnesty International , despite the fact they could resettle up to 2 million.
South Korea, Russia, Singapore, and Japan have also declined to offer any sort of help.
Here in the U.S., Secretary of State John Kerry announced this month that the U.S. will take in 85,000 refugees from around the world next year, and another 100,000 in 2017.
